back: A theoretical perspective that focuses only on observable behavior, ignoring internal mental states. Learning is defined as a change in behavior due to experience.
The father of behaviorism, famous for the 'Little Albert' experiment which proved fear could be conditioned.
Proposed by Thorndike: Behaviors followed by favorable consequences are more likely to occur; those followed by unfavorable consequences are less likely.
CLEP Trap: This is the foundation for Skinner's Operant Conditioning.

back: Learning through association where a neutral stimulus becomes capable of eliciting a response after being paired with a stimulus that naturally causes the response (Pavlov).
CLEP Trap: Confused with Operant Conditioning (which relies on consequences, not association).

back: In classical conditioning, the thing that naturally triggers a response without any learning (e.g., food, loud noise).
In classical conditioning, the natural, unlearned reaction to a stimulus (e.g., salivating at food).
In classical conditioning, a previously neutral stimulus that, after association with the UCS, triggers a reaction (e.g., the bell).
In classical conditioning, the learned reaction to the Conditioned Stimulus (e.g., salivating at the bell).
CLEP Trap: The CR is usually the same action as the UCR, but it is triggered by the CS instead of the UCS.

back: Responding to stimuli that are similar to the Conditioned Stimulus (e.g., fearing all dogs after being bitten by one).
Responding ONLY to the specific Conditioned Stimulus and not similar ones (e.g., fearing the math teacher but not the history teacher).
The weakening of the Conditioned Response when the CS is presented without the UCS repeatedly.
CLEP Trap: Confused with forgetting; it is unlearning the association.

back: Learning in which voluntary behavior is strengthened or weakened by consequences (Skinner).
CLEP Trap: Confused with Classical Conditioning (which deals with involuntary/reflexive responses).

back: ADDING a pleasant stimulus to INCREASE a behavior (e.g., giving gold stars).
CLEP Trap: 'Positive' means adding something, not necessarily 'good' in a moral sense.

back: REMOVING an unpleasant stimulus to INCREASE a behavior (e.g., waiving homework if classwork is done).
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Often confused with Punishment. Negative Reinforcement INCREASES behavior; Punishment DECREASES behavior.

back: ADDING an unpleasant stimulus to DECREASE a behavior (e.g., giving detention).
CLEP Trap: 'Positive' means adding a stimulus (even a bad one).

back: REMOVING a pleasant stimulus to DECREASE a behavior (e.g., taking away a phone).
CLEP Trap: Confused with Negative Reinforcement. Ask: Is the behavior increasing or decreasing?

back: Reinforcing EVERY correct response. This is best for teaching NEW behaviors.
Reward is given after a set NUMBER of responses. Result: High response rate with a pause after reward.
Reward is given after an unpredictable NUMBER of responses (e.g., slot machines). Result: High, steady rate; most resistant to extinction.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: This is the schedule most resistant to extinction.

back: Reward is given for the first response after a set TIME period. Result: 'Scalloped' pattern (cramming before the time is up).
Reward is given for the first response after changing TIME periods (e.g., pop quizzes). Result: Slow, steady response.
Reinforcing successive approximations toward a target goal (e.g., reinforcing holding a pencil, then scribbling, then writing).
Using a high-frequency (preferred) activity as a reinforcer for a low-frequency (less preferred) activity (e.g., 'Eat your veggies, then you get dessert').
A system where tokens are earned for good behavior and exchanged for backup reinforcers (prizes). Common in special ed and clinical settings.
Encouraging a behavior so much that the student gets sick of it and stops (e.g., letting a student throw spitballs until tired of it).
The first stage of memory that holds raw sensory data for a very brief time (1-3 seconds). Requires ATTENTION to move info to working memory.
The 'workbench' of the mind where conscious processing happens. Limited capacity (7 +/- 2 items) and duration (20-30 secs).
Grouping bits of information into larger, meaningful units to extend working memory capacity.
Rote repetition to keep information in working memory.
CLEP Trap: Less effective for long-term learning than Elaborative Rehearsal.

back: Connecting new information to existing long-term memory (deep processing).
CLEP Trap: The preferred method for meaningful learning.

back: Long-term memory of personal experiences and events (e.g., your prom).
Long-term memory of facts, concepts, and rules (e.g., 2+2=4).
Long-term memory of 'how-to' skills (e.g., riding a bike). Often unconscious.
When OLD information blocks the recall of NEW information (e.g., old phone number blocks new one).
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Confused with Retroactive. Focus on what is being forgotten (the NEW info).

back: When NEW information wipes out or blocks OLD information (e.g., learning Spanish makes you forget French).
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Focus on what is being forgotten (the OLD info).

back: The tendency to remember the beginning (Primacy) and end (Recency) of a list best, forgetting the middle.
Knowledge about one's own thinking processes ('Thinking about thinking'). Includes planning, monitoring, and evaluating.
A step-by-step procedure that GUARANTEES a solution (e.g., a recipe).
A general rule of thumb or mental shortcut that usually works but isn't guaranteed (e.g., guessing).
The inability to use an object or tool for a new function (e.g., not realizing a shoe can be a hammer).
When prior learning HELPS new learning (e.g., Latin helps Spanish).
When prior learning HINDERS new learning (e.g., driving on the right hinders driving on the left).
Mental building blocks or 'folders' used to organize information (Piaget).
Fitting new information into an EXISTING schema (e.g., calling a zebra a 'horse').
CLEP Trap: Confused with Accommodation. Assimilation changes the info to fit the schema.

back: Changing an existing schema or creating a new one to fit new information (e.g., creating a 'zebra' schema).
CLEP Trap: Confused with Assimilation. Accommodation changes the schema to fit the info.

back: The drive to find balance between assimilation and accommodation. Disequilibrium motivates learning.
The realization that objects exist even when unseen. Developed during the Sensorimotor stage (0-2 years).
Piaget's second stage (2-7 years). Characterized by symbolic thought, egocentrism, and lack of conservation.
Inability to see things from another's perspective. Characteristic of the Preoperational stage.
Understanding that quantity stays the same despite changes in shape/appearance. Lacking in Preoperational; developed in Concrete Operational.
CLEP Trap: Classic test: Water in tall vs wide glass.

back: Piaget's third stage (7-11 years). Characterized by logical thinking about concrete objects and mastery of conservation.
CLEP Trap: Cannot yet think abstractly or hypothetically.

back: Piaget's fourth stage (11+ years). Characterized by abstract thinking, hypotheticals, and deductive reasoning.
The gap between what a learner can do alone and what they can do with help. Where learning happens (Vygotsky).
Temporary support given by a More Knowledgeable Other to help a learner in the ZPD.
Children talking to themselves. Vygotsky viewed it as self-regulation (good); Piaget viewed it as egocentric (immature).
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Know the difference in interpretation between Vygotsky and Piaget.

back: Age 6-12 (Elementary). Key crisis: Competence in schoolwork and social setting. Failure leads to inferiority.
CLEP Trap: CRITICAL STAGE for Ed Psych. Mnemonic: 'Dusty Dinosaur' (Industry/Dust).

front: Erikson Stage 5: Identity vs. Role Confusion
back: Adolescence (12-18). Key crisis: 'Who am I?'. Peer relationships are dominant.
Morality based on self-interest: avoiding punishment (Stage 1) or getting rewards (Stage 2).
Morality based on social laws and rules: seeking approval (Stage 3) or obeying authority (Stage 4).
Morality based on universal principles and ethics (Stage 5/6). Laws can be broken if unjust.
Doing an activity for its own sake (enjoyment, curiosity).
Doing an activity for a reward or to avoid punishment.
Giving an extrinsic reward for something already intrinsically motivated can DECREASE the intrinsic motivation.
CLEP Trap: Trap: Don't reward students for what they already love doing.

back: How students explain their successes and failures (Weiner). Dimensions: Locus, Stability, Controllability.
Result of attributing failure to Internal, Stable, and Uncontrollable causes ('I'm stupid and can't change it').
Belief in one's capability to execute a SPECIFIC task (Bandura).
CLEP Trap: Confused with Self-Concept (which is general). Self-Efficacy is task-specific.

back: Focus on improving and understanding. Errors are part of learning.
CLEP Trap: Better for long-term success than Performance Goals.

back: Focus on looking good or getting high grades. Errors are viewed as failure.
Needs that must be met first: Physiological, Safety, Belonging, Esteem.
CLEP Trap: If a student is sleeping/hungry, these needs override learning.

back: General Intelligence factor. If you are good at one area, you are likely good at others.
Theory that there are 8 distinct, independent intelligences (e.g., Linguistic, Musical, Interpersonal).
Intelligence has 3 parts: Analytical (book smart), Creative (novelty), and Practical (street smart).
Cognitive style: Perceives patterns as a whole, socially oriented, prefers group work and structure.
Cognitive style: Perceives separate parts, task-oriented, prefers working alone.
Federal law guaranteeing Free Appropriate Public Education (FAPE) to students with disabilities.
Students must be educated with non-disabled peers to the maximum extent appropriate.
CLEP Trap: Does not always mean full inclusion, but 'appropriate' inclusion.

back: Legal document detailing goals and services for a student with a disability. Created by a team.
Civil rights law for students who need accommodations (e.g., ADHD) but not specialized instruction (IEP).
Significant gap between POTENTIAL (IQ) and ACHIEVEMENT. Not caused by low IQ or sensory issues.
CLEP Trap: Trap: LD students often have average or above-average intelligence.

back: Assessment used DURING instruction to guide teaching. Low stakes (e.g., exit ticket).
Assessment used AFTER instruction to judge mastery. High stakes (e.g., final exam).
Compares a student's score to OTHERS (e.g., grading on a curve, percentile rank).
Compares a student's score to a STANDARD (e.g., driver's license test, '80% correct').
The consistency of test results (e.g., getting the same score twice).
Does the test measure what it is supposed to measure?.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: A test can be reliable but NOT valid. It cannot be valid unless it is reliable.

back: The middle score in a distribution. Best measure of central tendency when there are extreme outliers.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Use Median, not Mean, when outliers are present.

back: A measure of how spread out the scores are from the mean.
CLEP Trap: Low SD = scores clustered; High SD = scores spread out.

back: Percentage of people scoring AT or BELOW a given score.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: 90th percentile does NOT mean you got 90% of questions right.

back: A score (e.g., 5.2) indicating performance equal to an average student of that grade/month.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: 5.2 does NOT mean a 2nd grader is ready for 5th grade work.

back: Teacher-centered, structured, explicit teaching. Best for basic skills and facts.
Student-centered approach where students figure out rules themselves (Bruner).
Introductory material given BEFORE a lesson to help students organize new info (Ausubel).
Students working in mixed-ability groups. Requires Positive Interdependence and Individual Accountability.
CLEP Trap: TRAP: Must have individual accountability to avoid 'hitchhiking'.

back: Cooperative learning method where each student becomes an expert on one part and teaches others.
Teacher's awareness of what is going on in all parts of the room at all times (Kounin).
CLEP Trap: 'Eyes in the back of the head'.

back: Correcting one student's behavior influences others to behave (Kounin).
Hierarchy of thinking skills: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, Create.
Measures the relationship between variables. DOES NOT prove cause and effect.
Number from -1.0 to +1.0 indicating strength and direction of relationship.
Research that manipulates variables and uses Random Assignment. The ONLY method to prove cause-and-effect.
The variable the researcher changes or manipulates (e.g., teaching method).
The variable being measured (e.g., test scores).
Studying the SAME people over a long period of time.
CLEP Trap: Pros: tracks growth. Cons: expensive, attrition.

back: Studying different age groups at the SAME time.
